Small skier triggered wind slab around 6800 ft. just outside the Flathead Avalanche Center advisory area near Mt. Gould in Glacier National Park. The slope was a steep (>35 degree) slope and the avalanche initiated on a rocky part of a south-facing slope. The slope was well off of any ridge, but in a wind loaded pocket. The slide was small (20-30 ft. wide) and ranged in depth from 4 inches to 12 inches at the deepest point. 

Also, it was fairly easy to trigger loose sluffs (moist, but not quite wet) on most slopes steeper than 35 degrees. With the underlying melt-freeze crust serving as a good bed surface, these sluffs were able to entrain a decent amount of snow and travel fairly far downhill. They are certainly large enough to knock someone over or off your sled.

Triple Arches continued to avalanche 05/23/2019 after Road Crew and Forecasters exited the road, refilling their exit cut. On Monday (05/27/2019) cyclists enjoying memorial blue skies and warm temps crossed the debris pile at Triple Arches and continued up the road. Triple Arches began avalanching mid-day, trapping 13 cyclists on the other side for nearly 8 hours. NPS rangers responded to the incident.  E. Peitzsch and J. Hageness were informed of the incident around 530pm and responded by 8pm to evaluate snow stability and permit a Road Crew worker to dig a new path through the debris to free the cyclists. All were unharmed and returned to West Glacier by 1030pm that evening.
